Description: Lid sherd of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery stemmed bowl; white slip; interior reserved; exterior, from top: part of tongue pattern around handle (now lost); below, two narrow brown bands above black-figure decoration consisting of lion to right (rump missing; added red on underbelly, mane and possibly face); incised rising, pendant and full rosettes with red centres as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Lemos places this sherd in Stage 1 of Group D of the Sphinx and Lion Style. Although the imagery is lively, the execution of the figures is loose and careless.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 315, no. 1346, pl. 174)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 83, no. 37, pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2136) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
